Operations on Strings

In TJS2, strings are treated pseudo-objects of the String class, but the String class does not actually exist, nor are they truly objects of a String class (however, using the typeof operator on a string returns "String").
Nevertheless, by treating strings as objects, several methods and properties become available.

length

The length property returns the length of the string. Note that this is a property, not a method. However, you cannot assign a value to this property.

In TJS, all characters are handled internally as UNICODE, so both full-width and half-width characters are counted as 1 character.

Example:
    var str = "abc漢字";
    var n = str.length;  // 5 is assigned to n
    var n = "abc漢字".length; // This is also assigned 5

'numeric' Property

By specifying a numeric value as an indirect property, you can access the character at that position.
For example, if str is a string or an expression representing a string, str[0] will be a string representing the first character.
An exception occurs if the number is beyond the length of the string or is negative (however, an empty string is returned for the position immediately following the last character).

Assignment expressions cannot be created.

Example:
    var str = "abcdef";
    var c = str[0];  // 'a' is assigned to c
    var c = str[2];  // 'c' is assigned to c
    str[3] = 'A'; // Assignment is not possible, resulting in an error
    var c = str[100]; // Error occurs because the value of c is out of range
    var c = str[6]; // Empty string '' is assigned

charAt

The charAt method returns the character at the specified position. It behaves similarly to the 'numeric' property, but it always returns an empty string for out-of-range positions (without throwing an exception).

Syntax : charAt()

Example:
    var str = "abcdef";     var c = str.charAt(3); // 'd' is assigned to c

indexOf

The indexOf method returns the position of a substring.

Syntax : indexOf([,])
Searches for the within the string starting from and returns the position where it is first found. A return value of 0 indicates the beginning of the string. A return value of -1 means it was not found. If is omitted, the search starts from the beginning of the string.


Example:
    var str = "abcdefghijkl";
    var n = str.indexOf("fgh"); // 5 is assigned to n
    var n = str.indexOf("xyz"); // -1 is assigned to n

toLowerCase

This method takes no arguments.
toLowerCase returns a string with all alphabetic characters converted to lowercase.
Full-width characters are not converted.

These methods do not affect the original string.

Example:
    var lwr="ABCDEF".toLowerCase(); // "abcdef" is assigned to lwr

Note
In the current version of TJS2, conversion is performed only for characters with character codes less than 0x80.

toUpperCase

This method is the reverse of toLowerCase, returning a string with lowercase alphabetic characters converted to uppercase.

substring

The substring method returns a substring of the string.

Syntax : substring([,])
Returns a substring of characters starting from . It does not affect the original string. If is omitted, all characters from to the end of the string are returned.
Note that the meaning of the arguments differs from the corresponding method in JavaScript.

Example:
    var ss="abcdefghijkl".substring(3,3); // "def" is assigned to ss

substr

Same as substring.

sprintf

The sprintf method formats a string.

Syntax : sprintf(argument, argument, ....)
Treats the string as a format string and returns a string formatted similarly to the sprintf function in C. It does not affect the original string.

Example:
    var formatted = "%04X %c %5d".sprintf(v1, v2, dic[v1]);

replace

The replace method performs string replacement.

Syntax : replace(, )
Performs string replacement according to a regular expression pattern and returns the resulting string. It does not affect the original string.
For behavior, please refer to the replace method of the RegExp class.

split

The split method splits a string.

Syntax : split(, <(reserved)>, )
Returns an array object containing the results of the string split.

Please also refer to the split method of the Array class (note the order of the arguments).

escape

The escape method converts a string into a format that can be represented as a TJS string literal. Symbols such as \ and " are all escaped using the \ symbol so they are not interpreted for special purposes.

Syntax : escape()
Returns the escaped string. It does not affect the original string.


Example:
    var escaped = str.escape(); // " in str is converted to \", \ to \\, etc.

trim

The trim method returns a string with leading and trailing whitespace removed. It does not affect the original string.
Leading and trailing whitespace refers to characters with character codes U+0001 to U+0020. This includes ASCII control characters but does not include so-called full-width (Zen-kaku) spaces.
If there are multiple consecutive whitespaces at the beginning or end, they are all removed.

Syntax : trim()
Returns a string with leading and trailing whitespace characters deleted. It does not affect the original string.


Example:
    var str = "  Hoge ".trim(); // str is "Hoge".

reverse

The reverse method returns a string with the character order reversed. It does not affect the original string.
In the current version of TJS2, operation for strings containing UTF-16 surrogate pairs is not guaranteed.

Syntax : reverse()
Returns a string with the character order reversed. It does not affect the original string.


Example:
    var str = "Hoge".reverse(); // str is "egoH".

repeat

The repeat method returns a string consisting of the original string repeated the specified number of times. It does not affect the original string.

Syntax : repeat(count)
Returns a string that repeats this string 'count' times. It does not affect the original string.


Example:
    var str = "Hoge".repeat(3); // str is "HogeHogeHoge".
